text:
If your content strategy includes a podcast, how did you define your strategy, decide theme? Who is responsible for producing it?

context:
• My pov is that a podcast should serve larger branding and messaging goals. so in my current b2b case, align to org mission and core messaging
• I’m running into a team who want to produce a podcast on a niche topic only relevant to a very small portion of our audience. We don’t have endless resources and I think this effort would dilute others so I’m blocking it. But doing so is draining and causing team friction
I wonder if i’m being inflexible in my approach. What’s been your approach & experience?

elements.text:
If your content strategy includes a podcast, how did you define your strategy, decide theme? Who is responsible for producing it?

context:
My pov is that a podcast should serve larger branding and messaging goals. so in my current b2b case, align to org mission and core messaging

I’m running into a team who want to produce a podcast on a niche topic only relevant to a very small portion of our audience. We don’t have endless resources and I think this effort would dilute others so I’m blocking it. But doing so is draining and causing team friction
I wonder if i’m being inflexible in my approach. What’s been your approach & experience?

text:
Our podcast is run and hosted by our Community Manager, who uses his ties to our customer community to source guests.

The coverage and topics used to be for our core target audience (Customer Success) but he has since expanded the podcast to cover the SaaS field in general.

He did this because according to his performacne numbers, the episodes that got the highest traffic and engagement were not the ones that served a niche audience.

Definitely depends on how small this audience is. But if it's a small but really important group, it could be worthwhile (LemonPie example).

text:
We launched our podcast 2/3 weeks ago, and first let me say, it’s a lot of work :sweat_smile:

Define our strategy - we’re a small, stratup team and if I’m honest, I think there’s been a lot of back and forth on this. However, now I’ve realised how much work it is, I’m viewing the podcast as a longer term, branding building activity (that will hopefully generate leads in the future) with more TOFU content and topics that are specific to our ICP.

As it takes so much time, I’ve now decided to focus almost all other channels on more MOFU/BOFU content in the hope to drive leads in the shorter term.

FYI I’m a one person marketing team at a startup and I have a freelancer help with the production etc.

I do host the show - although ideally a community person with a background similar to our ICP would do this, but we’re stilling recruiting for this person.

I haven’t had trouble finding guests so far - people have even asked to come on as a guest since we launched!

However, I guess if that small niche audience is where the money lies (excuse the crude phase), then maybe the ROI would be worth it :woman-shrugging:

In summary, considering the resource required to create and distribute a podcast, I’m in your camp.

Hope this helps! :slightly_smiling_face:

Hope this helps!

text:
Hey <@U016A2ADU3F> Our weekly podcast (B2B SaaS) is run out of marketing. We do all guest sourcing, prep, recruitment, promo, etc. in house, but we work with an agency that does the final edit on audio mix (we’re looking at bringing this in house later this year).

Our goals are aligned to top-of-funnel supporting both awareness and ABM strategies, but it’s also been an amazing way for us to re-engage customers and build a community given how many touches we have with guests before, during, and after recording. Happy to answer any Qs if you want to talk through anything.

elements.text: Hey

Our weekly podcast (B2B SaaS) is run out of marketing. We do all guest sourcing, prep, recruitment, promo, etc. in house, but we work with an agency that does the final edit on audio mix (we’re looking at bringing this in house later this year).

Our goals are aligned to top-of-funnel supporting both awareness and ABM strategies, but it’s also been an amazing way for us to re-engage customers and build a community given how many touches we have with guests before, during, and after recording. Happy to answer any Qs if you want to talk through anything.

text:
I had the fortunate opportunity to work with a very well known podcast production company, and they spent A TON of time just zeroing in on the premise of the podcast itself.

This came down to a ton of market research and understanding the “neighborhoods” the podcast might potentially live in. I was surprised when the mapped out the overlap in audiences and what those different neighborhoods looked like. It definitely influenced our decision on the approach, especially as we started thinking about the podcast’s primary, secondary, and tertiary audience’s were.

The market research, in my opinion, is absolutely critical in this case, because there has to be a level of distinction, but also distribution so you can end up in those “recommended” lists.

text: Curious about experience with canonical links. I’m going to start a blog on my company’s site in addition to our existing Medium and want to prioritize site traffic. I’ve seen a folks here who seem to trust canonical links to do that. Meanwhile, in my last role, an SEO wizard told me he didn’t trust canonical links. His rec was to avoid duplicate content at all costs. If you’ve used them/use them regularly, how do you validate that they’re not hurting your rank? I’m a bit new to SEO and appreciate your insight!

elements.text: Curious about experience with canonical links. I’m going to start a blog on my company’s site in addition to our existing Medium and want to prioritize site traffic. I’ve seen a folks here who seem to trust canonical links to do that. Meanwhile, in my last role, an SEO wizard told me he didn’t trust canonical links. His rec was to avoid duplicate content at all costs. If you’ve used them/use them regularly, how do you validate that they’re not hurting your rank? I’m a bit new to SEO and appreciate your insight!

text: Lots of questions to ask here, but I'd start with how Medium is going for you? If good, where is that traffic coming from (Medium itself or from Google?)

elements.text: Lots of questions to ask here, but I'd start with how Medium is going for you? If good, where is that traffic coming from (Medium itself or from Google?)

text: We use them constantly because we syndicate stories out to quality news publications. (I work at <https://studio.stacker.com/|Stacker Studio>.) Canonicals in an of themselves do not cause any sort of penalty. They're built for a purpose -- to tell Google where the original version of the story is. As long as you're not changing up the article when you republish it, you should be fine.

elements.text: We use them constantly because we syndicate stories out to quality news publications. (I work at
Stacker Studio

.) Canonicals in an of themselves do not cause any sort of penalty. They're built for a purpose -- to tell Google where the original version of the story is. As long as you're not changing up the article when you republish it, you should be fine.

text: <@UUXMCJQ15> Medium itself (and LinkedIn posts pointing to Medium), so we want to keep that, and will continue to publish some topics (thought leadership type things) exclusively there. However, some of the posts we have there will make sense for our on-site blog, which will be more about learning and product features.

text:
Canonicals have a purpose and can be used effectively, but Google may also ignore them. <https://www.gsqi.com/marketing-blog/google-ignore-rel-canonical-different-content/amp/|https://www.gsqi.com/marketing-blog/google-ignore-rel-canonical-different-content/amp/>

I have encountered many, many times where the canonical was ignored. Google may honor the canonical, or it may not, there's no way of speaking concretely one way or another.

attachments.fallback: Google's Algorithms Can Ignore Rel Canonical When URLs Contain Different Content. Here's Proof.
attachments.text: Glenn Gabe of GSQi explains how Google can ignore rel canonical when urls contain different content. Google recently explained this can happen. Here's proof.
attachments.title: Google's Algorithms Can Ignore Rel Canonical When URLs Contain Different Content. Here's Proof.

elements.text: Canonicals have a purpose and can be used effectively, but Google may also ignore them.
https://www.gsqi.com/marketing-blog/google-ignore-rel-canonical-different-content/amp/
I have encountered many, many times where the canonical was ignored. Google may honor the canonical, or it may not, there's no way of speaking concretely one way or another.
